content.description: Yellow Fin may look a little scrappy at first glance, but closer inspection reveals a true gem. The rock is mostly great, the movement wonderfully varied, and the positions wild.  After a brief stint on straightforward holds at the bottom, you're quickly forced into compression between the two aretes. I'm 5'9" with a plus 2 and was just able to make the spans.  This section would be harder and likely more frustrating with a much shorter reach  After an optional shake around to the right, wrestle through a few more bolts of compression before a wild palming sequence to get established in the hanging corner.  Quickly turn the arete to the right and surf up fun in-cuts to the final roof looming above.  Execute a wild hanging mantle onto the slab and crimp your way to chains and glory up and to the right.
content.location: Look for the hanging column halfway up the cliff with the second roof above it.  Yellow Fin is is the 3rd bolted line downstream of Colorsplash (the only trad climb in the immediate vicininty) and just downstream from the large column/bench at the base of the wall.

content.description: This is another basalt ultra-classic that mysteriously receives a sandbag split-grade in the guidebook.  As if there were any doubt this was at least 12d!  Unless you're a honed basalt master, this will probably feel like 5.13.  Perhaps the sandbag is due to the fact that the route is relatively easy most of the way, with a sinister double crux between the 3rd & 4th bolts.
content.protection: Bolts.  This route is the most runout in the Upper Gorge.  Consider TR rehearsal, or hanging double-length slings off the 4th and 5th bolts so you can clip before executing the cruxes.
content.location: Red Columns, the next "outy" left of Big Tuna

content.description: This excellent stembox makes for a great warmup: Tightly bolted and fairly easy climbing for most of its length with a harder section culminating in a brief crux at about two-thirds height. Very enjoyable - the only detractor is it can be a bit sandy but this would surely improve with more traffic.
content.protection: A dozen or so bolts to a lower-off.
content.location: A little ways left of a collection of large boulders resting against the wall, this route starts just left of a small seat formed by a flat rock platform at the base of Playing in Traffic.  Look for the obvious stembox. Another helpful landmark is that this route is the first route left of the mixed route Spellbound which sports only three bolts down low.

content.description: Classic arete climbing on bomber rock! Starts off with a boldery sequence through the 2nd bolt followed by a 5.6 run-out to the 3rd bolt, don't be intimidated. Then comes moderately hard moves with multiple balance and dynamic cruxes.
content.location: Upper gorge. upstream from E-Type. Starts to the left of a roof

content.description: Right of Naxis and left of Up Country, the left facing corner also includes face and arete moves and a cool bulge at the top on the usual excellent rock.
content.location: About a dozen columns right of E-Type

content.description: A very good sport route, Tomb of Love has some great movement.  The crux is a mix of stems and finger sized slots, and if you get through that you will be rewarded with a very fun pull around the roof.  Shares anchors with Hot Lava, the original 5.13 of the Upper Gorge.
content.location: In Middle Earth Crag, just left of a very large bush, in between the E-Type area and Naxis area.

content.description: An excellent and difficult stemming/pressing problem up a right-facing, 90-degree corner. Somewhat relentless with a definite crux at mid-height, you’ll find lots of stances, but upwards progress is not so easy.
content.location: Two side-by-side climbs share an anchor (visible from the ground on an overhanging panel of rim rock) and stand alone from the other climbs in the area: Octane 96 and Starkist. Starkist is the righthand of the two. These routes start atop one of several large boulders at the base of the wall. These large boulders are an obvious landmark.

climbs.name: Special Effects
climbs.fa: Tom Egan April 1982/Jeff Frizzell March 1992 to a higher anchor

content.description:
Another engaging sport climb in the Upper Gorge.  Tricky movement from bottom to top, but the meat of the climbing is in the middle as you pass through stems, liebacks, and steeper moves. 

 Initially this climb ended before pulling the overhang, but early on it was routed up and left.  The finish isn’t the hardest section, with big holds behind a block that seems very nebulously attached to the rest of the cliff.  This anchor is also hard to clean from. I balked here the second time I tried but my friend Forrest kicked the block on rappel and it seemed solid. If you’d like to finish the original method, traverse over to the Urge/Color Splash anchor.

One of the few moderates in the Upper... 

  Start out with some face moves before moving hard right and gaining a dihedral. Stem and lieback up the dihedral to a bolted anchor.
content.location: On the Vatican Wall a few routes left of E Type Jag.

content.description: This excellent route is similar in style and quality to the Catalyst.  Its a bit harder than the Catalyst, however, with arguably better movement, though not as classic in appearance.
content.location: Red Columns, this is the next "Outy" to the left of The Urge

content.description: Quite well featured face climbing by gorge standards.  The '92 guidebook suggests that it is often wet or dirty due to a seep in the leaky canal, but this has not been a problem. Not a classic but it would be popular in a more heavily visited area.
content.location: Probably the third bolted line east (upstream) of the approach gully.  Big holds on weathered but solid rock.

content.description: A wonderful climb with some dashing moves up a bucketed arete.
content.location: 4th route downstream of the gully.

content.description: One of the best moderate sport lines on Basalt in Smith.  Start by soloing a little pedestal, clip a bolt and enjoy the fun sequences, stem, crimp, jug, repeat!  You can top rope 4 5.12s off this route too!  At the top you can go up/right or left.
content.location: After passing the bucket arete of E-Type Jag, this is the next heavily chalked route, it has a moderate clearing underneath and starts with a 20 foot pillar, above this is the stemming box of Naxis.

content.description:
Amazing stemming...long reaches between good holds.   The moves are well protected by bolts and fun. A good warm up for Upper Gorge climbers, a good project for mortals. 

  Being tall helps on this route as the stems in this shallow stem box are wide and the reaches are long.
content.location: Middle Earth, upstream from E Type Jag a couple hundred yards.

content.description:
A route for those who carry a rack to the Upper Gorge...it doesn't see much traffic. 

  Climb the clean crack above a pedestal that goes from good hands to fingers near the top. Step left on the ledge to a bolted anchor. 

  The route is easily identified by the perfectly circular soft ball sized hole at the start of the route on top of the pedestal.
content.location: Second Pedestal area...down stream from E-type Jag about 50 yards.

content.description: Excellent arete and face moves; a classic basalt line.
content.location: One of the last full length routes as the wall peters out at the upstream, eastern end.  Mojomatic is a clean, well defined arete line from top to bottom.

content.description: The *other* Just Do It. Unfortunately this one is of lesser renown and quality, and is nearly as unattainable considering it requires the audacity and ambition to actually carry a rack to the Upper Gorge. It is, however, a decent climb and a suitable warmup for Colorsplash and Hail Mary (both of which are excellent).See location details. Climb the right side of a 20' high stubby pillar to a large ledge, then climb the crack on the left to an anchor. Above a good rest at mid-height is a crux that is easier than it appears from below.
content.location: Locate two tall, beautiful juniper trees just before arriving at the open staging area at the base of E-Type Jag. On the wall across from them and centered between them is a 20' high stubby pillar. Climb the right side of this.

content.description: Don't let the dirty and unprotected start dissuade you, Hail Mary is an excellent and well-protected climb that, along with Colorsplash, totally justifies the extra effort of bringing a rack down to the Upper Gorge.Begin by climbing up some loose and unprotected terrain (borderline PG13 but easy and reasonably secure) to a jug at 15' from which you can place a finger-sized cam overhead. From here the rock and protection dramatically improve. Typical Upper Gorge trickery is required to read the sequences, only this time you're executing above gear rather than bolts. Super fun and high-quality.
content.protection: 1x 0.1 Camalot or equivalent 2x 0.2 Camalots or equivalent 4x 0.3 Camalots (I recommend several different styles/brands of cams in this approximate size) 4x 0.4 Camalots (I recommend several different styles/brands of cams in this approximate size) 1x 0.5, 0.75, #1 Camalots No stoppers needed
content.location: A little difficult to describe, it is the first route right of the bolted lines of Mother Superior and The Sign of the Priest, and just left of the short pillar of Land of the Lost and Voodoo Child. The start is marked by an overhead, down-pointing and exfoliating flake with some plant matter wedged behind it.

content.description: Begin with some awkward stemming to a roof, pull the roof (bolt over the lip with an upside-down hanger) on the left, and continue up easier ground to a high anchor.
content.protection: 9 bolts to chain anchor. Currently no lower-offs.
content.location: The leftmost/first route you come to at the upstream walls. Begin just right of a long, low, chunky overhang that is head-height. The climb starts in tight brush at a guano-stained blob.

content.description: A great route that shares its first two thirds with the classic E-Type Jag up the pocketed arete, then steps left to the obvious pillar for a rest. From here, continue straight up the large left-facing corner above, avoiding Jag's big roof via a smaller one. Finally step back right to Jag's anchor.According to comments on the E-Type Jag description, this variation (also known as X-Type Jag?) was also put up by Jeff Frizzell, a decade later, supposedly to provide an easier option for those that were "cheating" through the direct roof of E-Type Jag. It seems to me that many climbing E-Type Jag will still stem to the pillar (if not fully stand on it) before pulling the roof, but perhaps the most "pure," albeit contrived, way to climb E-Type Jag is to avoid the pillar entirely and pull the roof directly. That said, E-Type Shag is a great route in its own right.
content.location: The hueco-covered arete capped by a large roof directly in front of the nice pine tree staging area.

content.description: Sweet jug haul through big roof!   Start with a pocketed arete up to a roof.   Swing out on jugs, race for the anchor.

A good route broken into two parts by a big ledge. Difficult moves up the initial corner leads to a ledge. Move right past a pointless chain anchor (straight up is the continuation of “Six Hits of Sunshine” - these two routes cross each other at the ledge), tiptoe up to make a clip, and continue stemming to a final runout to an anchor out left.
content.protection: 10x bolts. Chain anchor - currently no lower-offs.
content.location: A little tricky to identify but the line of Spellbound is easy to find because it has only three bolts down low (the rest being gear-protected). Immediately left of Spellbound is the striking and tightly bolted stem box of Virtual Beach. Drepane is the third bolted line left of Virtual Beach.

content.description:
Start in a little alcove just to the right of the E Type start.  After getting established a tricky palming move gets you to some good crack holds. Good luck trying to fit your right hands into the crack, and holding on to the arete on the left.  A fun crank from the ringlock crack to a good hold gives you a little respite. The second crux is more of the same, tiiny holds in the crack and ripples around the corner.  Then, without any respite, set up for a big deadpoint. 

  Like the Urge, expect this to feel plenty hard for the grade.  Its worth noting that pretty much all of Frizzel's testpeice's  in this grade range have been upgraded.
content.location: The first bolted line upstream (right) of E-Type Jag.  You can set up a top rope by climbing E Type, then moving right to the 11d top rope anchors (5th Dimension),then swinging right on the way down.

content.description: Pretty much the only column joint wide enough to crack climb in this section of the Upper.  A superb and physically demanding old school crack splits a sea of modern face climbs.
content.protection: Protects perfectly a la any of the classic Lower Gorge 5.10s
content.location: Immediately left of the prominant 'outie' column The Urge.

content.description: One of the best basalt routes in Oregon.
content.location: From the approach gully, this is the 3rd bolted route downstream, and likely the first with any chalk on it.

content.description: A fun "innie", Celibate Wives gets going right off the ground.  The real crux hits around the 4th bolt with multiple ways to attack the tough moves.  Commit to going left or right then you're rewarded with a great rest.  From here there is one more semi-crux sequence guarding the last bolt, but the challenge is from holding it all together.
content.location: 2 routes right of the striking arete "Mojomatic" towards the far right of the crag

content.description: This is a fun stemming problem a few climbs down from E-Type Jag.  It's a little crumbly because of so few ascents but would clean up nicely if the Upper Gorge saw more traffic.
content.protection: There are 7 bolts but a few aliens would sew up the run out to the anchor.  As is, the bolting job is pretty poor with the crux coming after the climbs only run-out.
content.location: This is the obvious stem box 5 climbs down from E-Type.

climbs.name: Blind Dogs Need Bones Too
climbs.fa: Mark Larisch, Tom Egan, Jeff Frizzell - 1989

content.description: A worthwhile route and a good warmup.Begin by scrambling up and right across terraced ledges until about 20’ off the ground. Reach left to clip the first bolt and enter into a wide stem. Continue stemming and face climbing up to a ledge and shared anchor.
content.location: A little ways right of the sharp arete of Mojomatic (currently identifiable by yellow hangers on a few bolts, though these may be better camouflaged in the near future) and just right of the seam of Hieroglyphics (bolts with red hangers, again, these may be better camouflaged in the future) are some stubby columns that can be third-classed onto from the left. The base here has a nice clearing/staging area.

content.description: Stemming and face climbing with a “nails”-hard crux moving off a jug at mid-height. The route culminates with a fun and improbable pull around a triangular roof.
content.location: The corner just left of Pink Primitive - they share the first bolt (or stick clip the second) then Black Nails moves left while PP continues straight up.

content.description:
This is the big prize in the Upper Gorge.  If there is a harder route on a basalt column anywhere in the world, I'd like to see it. 

  This route is the ultimate in a unique genre of double-arete column climbing, or "Outies" (vs. "Innies") as Jeff Frizzel sometimes called them.  If you're interested in achieving an ascent of this route, I recommend a gradual apprenticeship through the bolted columns of the Lower Gorge (routes such as Try to Be Hip & Catalayst) then working through the "outies" of the Upper (Mojomatic, Shark Infested, The Urge, Feminazis). 

  This route is sharp, thin and ultra technical.  The physical crux is getting to the 4th bolt, but the upper column is 12+ in its own right, without any significant rest.  As far as is known, this route has seen only 3 ascents.
content.location: This route is in the Red Columns section of the Upper Gorge.  The Red Columns are the furthest section of cliff downstream.  This route can be easily identified as one of only a couple "outies" on this section of cliff.  The rock has a unique maroon hue to it, and there is an obviously glued hold (aka "the secret agent") around the 2nd bolt.

content.description:
“My philosophy, in essence, is the concept of man as a heroic being, with his own happiness as the moral purpose of his life, with productive achievement as his noblest activity, and reason as his only absolute.”

 — Ayn Rand, Atlas Shrugged

Atlas Shrugged is another phenomenal climb in the Upper Gorge.  Overlooked in the initial Upper Gorge exploration, it links distant liebacks, underclings, and arete holds with improbable stems.  The business hits in the first 4 bolts, with some awesome technical & bouldery moves.  If you pass that you get a poor shake, and then straight into more hard climbing (12- to the top).
content.location: Downriver in the Red Columns, the fourth to last route with a brief section of exfoliating rock near the start.  Easily access to anchors stepping right from Almost Something.

content.description: I'm noting the approach gully here as an organizational aide; it breaks the Upper Gorge into two sections. The Urge and Shark Infested Waters, etc, are all downstream to the west. The Seep, E-Type, Mojomatic, etc. are all upstream to the east.Depending on water levels and how overgrown the base is, dropping in here may be the best and/or only approach.
content.protection: easy scramble, but slipping could be bad
content.location: A climber trail leads from the canal road to the top of the gully but if you've never located it before, you can also find it by hiking the rim of the Gorge eastward from the bend in the river.  It's the first and only break in this section of the gorge.

content.description: This stellar arete climb is likely the most attainable of the Upper Gorge 5.13s.  If you're looking to round-out your resume with something hard from the Upper Gorge, this is the route for you.  With five known ascents, this is by far the most popular 5.13 in the gorge, and is only slightly harder than The Urge, but less technical.
content.location: This route is in "Middle Earth", near the far up-stream end of the Upper Gorge.  Feminazis is the prominent prow just upstream from the large roofs of Blame it on Rio and Peruvian Skies.

content.description: Stellar basalt sport climbing with a small sprinkling of trad climbs. Mostly upper grades 11's and up.
